section: and inhibitory (i.e., they suppress the activity of the postsynaptic neuron and reducing the likelihood of an action potential),
text:
and inhibitory (i.e., they suppress the activity of the postsynaptic neuron and reducing the likelihood of an action potential),
some neurotransmitters are modulatory: they influence the overall activity of neural circuits by altering the strength or dynamics of synaptic communication.
–
For example, a modulatory neurotransmitter can influence the excitability of a postsynaptic neuron.

title: JXHC 1055
section: The action potential is always the same: same voltage and same duration.
text: The action potential is always the same: same voltage and same duration.

title: JXHC 1055
section: It is “all or nothing”: either sent or not sent.
text:
It is “all or nothing”: either sent or not sent.
So how do neurons communication different information?
–

title: JXHC 1055
section: Through spiking rate: the number of action potentials sent per second. The frequency at which action potentials are sent (i.e., how often they are sent) can vary.
text:
Through spiking rate: the number of action potentials sent per second. The frequency at which action potentials are sent (i.e., how often they are sent) can vary.
The spiking rate encodes meaning in neuronal communication.
–
For example, a neuron may exhibit a high spiking rate during specific activities, such as processing auditory information during speech, indicating its specialization in that domain.
–
Neurons that respond to similar types of information are often spatially grouped together, reflecting regional functional specialization.

title: JXHC 1055
section: The frontal lobe is the largest of the brain’s lobes and is responsible for a wide range of functions, including:
text:
The frontal lobe is the largest of the brain’s lobes and is responsible for a wide range of functions, including:

Executive Functions: Planning, decision-making, problem-solving, and goal-setting.
Motor Control: Houses the primary motor cortex, which controls voluntary movements.
Language Production: Includes Broca’s area, essential for speech production.
Attention and Focus: Regulates concentration and the ability to shift focus between tasks.
Emotional Regulation: Plays a role in managing emotions and social behavior.
Working Memory: Supports short-term memory and the manipulation of information.
Personality: Influences traits such as self-awareness, motivation, and social interactions.

title: JXHC 1055
section: The temporal lobe is located on the sides of the brain, near the ears, is responsible for functions including:
text:
The temporal lobe is located on the sides of the brain, near the ears, is responsible for functions including:

Auditory Processing: Houses the primary auditory cortex, which processes sounds and enables hearing.
Language Comprehension: Includes Wernicke’s area, essential for understanding spoken and written language.
Memory Formation: Plays a key role in forming and retrieving long-term memories, particularly through the hippocampus.
Emotional Processing: Involved in interpreting emotions and social cues, with contributions from the amygdala.
Object Recognition: Helps identify and categorize objects and faces through visual processing pathways.
Learning: Supports the acquisition of new information and skills.

title: JXHC 1055
section: The parietal lobe is located near the top and back of the brain and is involved in various sensory and integrative functions:
text:
The parietal lobe is located near the top and back of the brain and is involved in various sensory and integrative functions:

Sensory Processing: Interprets sensory information such as touch, temperature, pain, and pressure.
Spatial Awareness: Helps in understanding spatial relationships and navigating the environment.
Proprioception: Processes information about the position and movement of the body.
Integration of Sensory Input: Combines information from different senses to create a coherent perception of the world.
Attention and Focus: Plays a role in directing attention to relevant stimuli.
Mathematical and Logical Reasoning: Supports numerical processing and problem-solving tasks.

title: JXHC 1055
section: The occipital lobe is located at the back of the brain and is primarily responsible for visual processing. Its functions include:
text:
The occipital lobe is located at the back of the brain and is primarily responsible for visual processing. Its functions include:

Visual Perception: Processes visual information received from the eyes.
Color Recognition: Interprets and distinguishes different colors.
Motion Detection: Identifies and tracks movement within the visual field.
Spatial Processing: Helps in understanding spatial relationships and depth perception.
Object Recognition: Assists in identifying shapes, patterns, and objects.
Visual Memory: Stores and retrieves visual information for future reference.

title: JXHC 1055
section: The cerebral cortex enable complex cognitive functions such as:
text:
The cerebral cortex enable complex cognitive functions such as:

Perception: processing sensory input from various modalities (e.g., hearing, vision, touch, taste) to create a coherent representation of the environment.
Attention: it allows to select relevant stimuli while filtering out distractions
Memory: encoding, storing, and retrieving ot memories.
Language: speech production and comprehension.
Decision-Making: reasoning, problem-solving, and planning, which are essential for making informed decisions.
Conscious Thought: self-awareness and the ability to reflect on one’s thoughts and actions.

title: JXHC 1055
section: Scenario: Shifting from Ego Climate to Task Climate
text:
Scenario: Shifting from Ego Climate to Task Climate
A football coach had previously emphasized competition among players, frequently posting public leaderboards and rewarding only those who outperformed others. Over time, athletes began to focus solely on winning, felt anxious about mistakes, and reported enjoying the sport less.
Realizing the negative impact, the coach now wants to foster a task climate. Here’s what they can do:

Praise effort, improvement, and learning rather than just outcomes.
Set individual progress goals and celebrate personal bests.
Use private feedback focused on skill development.
Encourage teamwork and cooperation in training.
Introduce activities where success is measured by mastering new skills, not by comparison.
Reduce public comparisons and instead highlight collective achievements.

By making these changes, the coach can help athletes regain enjoyment and motivation through personal growth and mastery.

title: JXHC 1055
text:
Additional notes on Phineas Gage
Modern lesion reconstructions suggest the accident damaged ventromedial/orbitofrontal regions rather than the whole prefrontal cortex.
This helps explain changes in emotion regulation and social decision‑making more than pure working memory deficits.

Typical post‑accident changes reported: . These map well to vmPFC/OFC dysfunction in contemporary models.
Important nuances:

Reports come from historical case notes (Harlow and others) and vary in detail; some later evidence suggests partial recovery and preserved basic functions (he worked as a stagecoach driver for a time).
Single‑case narratives are powerful but limited — modern neuropsychology uses lesion groups, neuroimaging and tasks (e.g., Iowa Gambling Task) to test hypotheses derived from Gage’s case.
Other factors (seizures, infection, social reactions) may have contributed to behavioural changes; avoid over‑simplifying the story.

Why the case matters:

It was a landmark demonstration linking frontal damage to changes in personality and social behaviour, spurring the development of cognitive neuroscience of frontal lobes.
It motivates contrasts between dorsolateral (executive control, working memory) and ventromedial/orbitofrontal (value, emotion, decision) frontal functions.

Teaching suggestions:

Show a lesion reconstruction image and contrast expected deficits for vmPFC vs DLPFC lesions.
Use the case to introduce concepts like affective decision‑making, somatic‑marker ideas, and the limits of single‑case evidence.
Emphasise historical context and caution about simplistic “moral of the story” interpretations.


References (for slides/reading): Harlow (1868) clinical report; modern reviews/reconstructions (e.g., Damasio and colleagues; neuroanatomical reconstructions).
